zone.line: Shelley-Rolls Folders 1-4
*clasp
added
When Sir John Shelley-Rolls presented MS. Shelley adds. C. 4 to the Bodleian in 1946,
it comprised a leather box and a series of 'folders' (foolscap bifolia of lined paper)
which contained Shelley autograph sheets, still loose. The descriptions inscribed
on the folders are in Sir John's hand. He numbered the folders 1-38, and also
wrote in numbers in light pencil (sometimes not now legible) in the corners of the
original leaves themselves. Folders 27, 28 and 31 encompass inner folders
marked in Lady Shelley's hand (see also 29, unmarked). The handsome box,
of light brown leather lined with dark red silk, was part of Lady Shelley's
bequest to Sir John, for the table of contents inset into its inside lid (in the hand
of an amanuensis of Lady Shelley) is ticked off item by item in pencil with
Sir John's initials and dates in late January 1901; but this table does not
correspond to the present contents.
In Oct. 1985 - Feb. 1986 the loose sheets and folders were mounted into
standard Bodleian fascicules, and the box was adapted by cutting its
right-hand side at top and bottom to make a hinged flap.* The foliation
of 1946 (in which Philip Long, an Assistant in the Dept. of Western Manuscripts,
numbered original leaves and folders continuously and without distinction)
has been retained and should be cited as such, although the necessities
of mounting have dictated some changes of order. Fols. 141-177 and 210-2476 are now
kept out of sequence at the bottom of the box. B.C.B.-B 13 Feb. 1986
Readers are asked NOT to imitate the late Neville Rogers in writing announcements of their discoveries
into the manuscript itself.
MS. Shelley adds. c. 4, fols. 1-16
